growing.zone: 3-9 (German chamomile is grown as an annual; Roman chamomile is perennial)
growing.sun: Full sun preferred, tolerates partial shade
growing.water: Moderate; drought-tolerant once established but prefers consistent moisture without waterlogging
growing.soil: Light, well-draining soil with a neutral to slightly acidic pH (6-7)

planting.height: 6-24 inches (German is taller; Roman is lower-growing and more mat-forming)
planting.whenToPlant: Direct sow in spring after last frost or start indoors 4-6 weeks before
planting.propagation: Easily grown from seed (German); Roman can be propagated by division or cuttings
planting.depth: Sow seeds on the surface or lightly press into soil; they need light to germinate

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Regular harvesting of flowers encourages more blooms
careAndMaintenance.stakingOrSupport: Generally not required; taller German chamomile may benefit from support in windy spots
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: Roman chamomile overwinters as a low mat; German chamomile completes its lifecycle in one season

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: When flowers are fully open but before petals start to droop (for best flavor and potency)
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pinch or snip flower heads; for large harvests, a chamomile rake or comb can be used
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Air dry flower heads in a dark, well-ventilated space; store in airtight containers away from light and moisture
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Generally considered safe; excessive consumption may cause allergic reactions, especially in those sensitive to ragweed. Avoid during pregnancy in large amounts.
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Used in herbal teas (fresh or dried flowers); can be infused into syrups, desserts, or salad garnishes

medicinal.Digestive Soothing: Chamomile tea is traditionally used to ease indigestion, bloating, and gas thanks to its mild antispasmodic and carminative properties.
medicinal.Calming & Sleep: Well-known as a gentle relaxant to help reduce anxiety and promote restful sleep; often included in bedtime tea blends.
medicinal.Skin Care: Used topically as a wash or compress to soothe irritated skin, minor wounds, rashes, and insect bites. Contains anti-inflammatory compounds.
medicinal.Oral Health: Mild antiseptic properties make chamomile useful as a mouthwash for gum inflammation or canker sores.
medicinal.Anti-inflammatory: Drunk as tea or used in poultices for mild inflammation, including menstrual cramps or sore muscles.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Delicate, apple-like fragrance; historically called the 'plant's physician' because of its beneficial scent in gardens

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Generally not favored by deer or rabbits

funFacts: The name 'chamomile' comes from the Greek for 'earth apple,' referring to its scent.
It is sometimes interplanted in orchards to encourage healthy fruit trees.
Chamomile was a key herb in ancient Egyptian, Greek, and Roman medicine.
